College of Materials Science and Engineering, Chongqing University Chongqing 400044 China Lead salts poisoning was a great challenge for the catalysts application in selective catalytic reduction (SCR) reaction of NO x with NH3 in stationary sources. Herein, several typical transition metal (Cu, Co and Zr) oxides modified Mn-Ce/AC catalysts were prepared by impregnation method, and the effects of Cu, Co and Zr doping on resistance PbCl2 poisoning for the catalyst were investigated. The addition of three transition metal oxides improved the PbCl2 resistance of Mn-Ce/AC catalyst and maintained excellent low-temperature denitrification activity of the catalyst. The lead resistance performance of the three metal oxides followed: Cu > Co > Zr oxides. The NO conversion of Cu-doping catalyst after PbCl2 poisoning was only ca. 10% lower than that of fresh Mn-Ce/AC catalyst at 225 °C. Cu, Co and Zr doping could decrease the loss of specific surface area caused by poisoning, while Cu-doped catalyst showed lowest crystallinity of active components. Meanwhile, the contents of Mn4+ and chemisorbed oxygen in Cu-doped catalyst were higher than those in Co- or Zr-doped catalysts. Cu, Co and Zr doping improved the surface acidity and redox performance of the poisoned catalysts, with Cu-doped poisoned catalyst exhibiting nearly the same surface acidity and redox performance as the fresh Mn-Ce/AC catalyst. Furthermore, Cu doping could also improve NO adsorption and was in favor to the SCR process. Besides, in situ DRIFTS results showed that the catalytic reaction pathways of all the poisoned or modified catalysts were in accordance with both Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanisms. Finally, a possible anti-PbCl2 poisoning mechanistic model of (Cu, Co and Zr) oxides modified on Mn-Ce/AC catalyst was proposed. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Transition-metal oxides Mn-Ce/AC catalyst Low temperature SCR PbCl2-resistance 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides pollution was one serious air environmental pollution issue in the twenty-first century, occurring from fossil fuel combustion and automobile emissions, and causing the pollution issues such as photochemical smog, greenhouse effect and the acid rain [1–3]. Steel industry was the second greatest coal consuming and polluting emission source after the power industry, and the nitrogen oxides emission also ranked second in all industrial sector [4]. Therefore, reducing NO x emissions from steel industry, as represented in low-temperature (120–180 °C) sintering flue gas, was fundamental to China’s steel green and sustainable development. Due to the high denitrification efficiency, NH3-SCR technology was the most extensively utilized nitrogen removal technology [5,6]. The commercial V2O5-WO3/TiO2 catalyst was widely applied in coal-fired power plants, but it was not suitable for sintering flue gas by the following problems, such as easy deactivation, narrower active temperature window (300–400 °C), lower low-temperature activity and toxicity of vanadium species [7,8]. As a result, developing low-temperature and environmental-friendly NH3-SCR catalysts was vitally crucial. As for the variety of oxidation states, excellent redox and surface acidity, and ability to activate the reaction gas at lower temperature, MnO x -based catalysts became the research hotspot for NH3-SCR reaction in low-temperature flue gas [9,10]. A number of manganese-based catalysts, such as FeMnO x [11], MnO x -GdO x [12], CrOx-MnO x [13], MnO x -CeO x [14], MnO x /TiO2 [15] and CuO x -MnO x [16] catalysts, had gained considerable attention in recent years. In our earlier studies [8,17–19], Mn-Ce mixed oxides with activated carbon support, i.e. Mn-Ce/AC catalyst possessed extremely high application potential in low-temperature flue gas SCR denitrification for its good reaction activity and SO2/H2O resistance. In fact, heavy metal components, such as Pb, Zn, Hg, As, etc., had poisoning effects on the catalysts, which could not be ignored given the complex compositions of sintering flue gas [17,19–21]. As one of the typical toxic substances, lead existed mostly in the form of PbO and lead salts (PbCl2, Pb (NO3)2 and PbSO4, etc.) in the sintering flue gas, which would react chemically or physically with active components on catalysts surface, deactivating the catalysts [22–24]. As a result, the influence of Pb species on NH3-SCR catalysts had attracted much attention. Gao et al. found that PbO decreased the surface area and redox performance of V2O5/TiO2 catalyst [25]. Zhou et al. found that PbO destroyed Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the surface of Mn-Ce/TiO2 catalyst by interacting with MnO x [26]. In addition, PbCl2 acted through Brønsted acid sites on the surface of vanadium-titanium catalyst, reducing the V5+ content of the catalyst, thereby reducing the redox ability of the catalyst [22]. The poisoning effect of PbO and PbCl2 on CeO2-TiO2 catalyst was compared, and the results showed that PbO exhibited more serious deactivation effect on the catalyst, owing to its fewer surface Ce3+ and chemisorbed oxygen, lower surface acidity and NH3 adsorption [23]. In our previous studies, we investigated the poisoning effect of PbO and different types of lead salts (PbSO4, Pb(NO3)2 and PbCl2) on the Mn-Ce/AC catalyst [24,27], and found that PbCl2 performed more serious deactivation on the catalyst due to less surface acidity and poor redox properties. Considering the industrial application requirements, it was critical to design a kind of Mn-Ce/AC catalyst with high lead chloride resistance. Besides, enhancing the redox properties and surface acidity was identified as one of the most effective strategies to improve the lead resistance of Mn-Ce/AC catalyst for the causes of deactivation [28,29]. It had been found that the addition of Cu, Co and Zr oxides could increase the catalytic activity and resistance to alkali/heavy poisoning of some kinds of catalysts [30–33]. However, the promotional effects of these transition metal oxides on PbCl2-poisoned Mn-Ce/AC catalysts remained still unclear. In this work, three representative transition metal M (M= Cu, Co and Zr) oxides modified Mn-Ce/AC catalysts were prepared by the traditional impregnation method to investigate theirs anti-PbCl2 poisoning performance. The relationship between catalytic activity and physicochemical properties of these catalysts was investigated and corresponding PbCl2-poisoned resistance mechanism of Cu, Co and Zr oxides doping on Mn-Ce/AC catalysts was revealed. 2 Experiments 2.1 Catalysts preparation In this work, a series metal (Cu, Co and Zr) oxides doped Mn-Ce/AC catalysts were synthesized by traditional one-step impregnation method. The precursors such as 50 wt% Mn(NO3)3 (when used), Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (when used), Cu(NO3)3·3H2O (when used), Co(NO3)3·6H2O (when used) and Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (when used) were prepared as the impregnating solution. The pretreated AC was then placed in the impregnating solution and sonicated for 30 min, after which the slurry was evaporated in water bath at 80 °C until no liquid was existing, then dried it in the drying oven at 100 °C for 12 h and then calcined at 400 °C within a tube furnace under the N2 atmosphere for ca. 4 h. Finally, Cu-Mn-Ce/AC, Co-Mn-Ce/AC and Zr-Mn-Ce/AC catalysts were obtained, marked as CuMC/AC, CoMC/AC and ZrMC/AC, respectively. The molar ratios of Cu: Co: Zr: Mn was 0.5: 0.5: 0.5: 1. PbCl2-poisoned catalysts were also prepared by the impregnation method. The prepared fresh catalyst was impregnated in the solution containing 1 wt% PbCl2 solution. Then the mixed solution was evaporated totally in an 80 °C water bath, and then dried in a desiccator at 100 °C for 12 h. Finally, all samples were calcined at 400 °C within a tube furnace under the N2 atmosphere for ca. 4 h. The obtained catalysts of PbCl2-Mn-Ce/AC, PbCl2-Cu-Mn-Ce/AC, PbCl2-Co-Mn-Ce/AC and PbCl2-Zr-Mn-Ce/AC were abbreviated as PMC/AC, CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC, respectively. ICP-OES results of these samples were listed in Table 1, indicating that all metal elements were loaded on activated carbon successfully. The preparation details for the samples were shown in the Supplement Information (SI). 2.2 Catalytic performance test All catalysts were tested for catalytic activity and N2 selectivity in the fixed-bed quartz reactor (d = 8 mm) and 0.5 g catalyst was used for each run. The total reaction gas contained 500 ppm NH3, 500 ppm NO, 7% O2, 5% H2O (when using), 100 ppm SO2 (when using), and N2 was the balance gas, the total flow rate was 0.5 L/min and corresponded gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was just 30000 h−1. The GHSV was obtained by the formula (1). The outlet gas contents were measured using the flue gas analyzer of Antaris IGS from Thermo Fisher Scientific during 75–250 °C. The NO conversion rate and corresponding N2 selectivity results of the catalysts were obtained by the Eqs. (2) and (3). (1) G H S V = q v π h r 2 q v was corresponded to the total flow rate; h meant the height of the catalyst in the reactor; and r represented the inner radius of the reactor. (2) N O c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = ( 1 − [ N O ] o u t [ N O ] i n ) × 100 % (3) N 2 ( % ) = ( 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] o u t [ N O x ] i n + [ N H 3 ] i n − [ N O x ] o u t − [ N H 3 ] o u t ) × 100 % ICP-OES test, X-ray diffraction (XRD), Scanning electron microscope (SEM), BET measurement, NH3-TPD test, H2-TPR test, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiment and in situ DRIFTS experiment were used in the study to analyze physicochemical properties and reaction pathways for the catalysts. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance results In order to understand the degree of NO reduction over these prepared catalysts, the NH3-SCR performance test was carried out in the range of 75–250 °C, and the results were given in Fig. 1(a) and (b). From Fig. 1(a), CuMC/AC catalyst had the highest catalytic activity below 175 °C, but ZrMC/AC catalyst outperformed the other three fresh catalysts for catalytic activity above 175 °C in some degree. After PbCl2 poisoning, the NO conversion of all catalysts decreased. Among them, PMC/AC catalyst exhibited the lowest NO conversion, which was always below 45%, as shown in Fig. 1(b). CuPMC/AC demonstrated the highest catalytic conversion compared with the other three poisoned catalysts. Specifically, the NO conversion of CuPMC/AC catalyst exceeded 70% when the temperature was higher than 175 °C and reached a maximum of ca. 81% at 250 °C. In conclusion, the SCR conversion of NO for the lead-poisoned catalysts was in the order of CuPMC/AC > CoPMC/AC > ZrPMC/AC > PMC/AC. Fig. 1(c) and (d) depicted the N2 selectivity of fresh and PbCl2-poisoned catalysts, respectively. From Fig. 1(c), N2 selectivity for no polluted catalysts decreased rapidly with increased temperature from 75 to 250 °C, which was consistent with previous study [10]. Their N2 selectivity was as the following order: CuMC/AC > MC/AC > CoMC/AC > ZrMC/AC catalyst, implying that Cu-doping could improve N2 selectivity of MC/AC catalyst while Co- and Zr-doping was opposite. For PbCl2-poisoned catalysts as shown in Fig. 1(d), still CuPMC/AC catalyst exhibited excellent N2 selectivity and was always above 90% between 75 and 250 °C. In a word, among the three transition metals (Cu, Co, Zr) oxides, the Cu-modified PMC/AC catalyst had the best SCR performance at low temperatures and maintained the superior PbCl2 resistance. 3.2 XRD results XRD tests were conducted for studying the dispersion and crystallinity of active or poisoned components over these catalysts and XRD patterns for MC/AC, PMC/AC, CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC catalysts were given in Fig. 2. XRD diffraction patterns for MC/AC catalyst showed two distinct broad peaks located 40–50° and 20–30°, which were corresponding to (002) crystal plane of graphite crystal with layered structure and (100) crystal plane with a turbine graphite structure [34–36]. Studies reported that π-bond in graphite crystallite could accelerate NO oxidation to NO2 at low temperature with oxygen, thus facilitating the “fast SCR” reaction [37,38]. Numerous diffraction peaks could be also observed at 20–30° and 40–50° on PMC/AC catalyst, attributing to the crystallization for surface substance. Specifically, the diffraction peaks of MnO2 (22.2°, 31.5° and 42.4°, PDF#82–269), Mn2O3 (45.2°, PDF#33–0900) and CeO2 (48.3° and 53.9°, PDF#75–0151) appeared on these poisoned catalysts [19,21]. It indicated that some of the graphite crystallite of MC/AC catalyst was destroyed after lead poisoning, causing some new peaks to appear beyond 20–30° and 40–50°. After modification with transition metal oxides, the diffraction peaks intensity of the active component on the catalysts surface significantly reduced, indicating that CuO x , CoO x and ZrO x promoted the dispersion of the active ingredients which made them present over catalyst surface with a low crystallinity. The intensity of the corresponding diffraction peaks followed: PMC/AC > ZrPMC/AC > CoPMC/AC > CuPMC/AC catalyst. 3.3 BET results The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and the pore diameter distributions were given in Fig. 3, which revealed the pore structure characteristics of the samples. As seen from Fig. 3(a), desorption isotherms for the catalysts exhibited both type I and IV characteristics and possessed H4 hysteresis loops, implying that the pore structures for the samples included both micropores and mesopores [39]. It could also be demonstrated from pore diameter distributions in Fig. 3(b). The results of the textural properties of the samples were summarized ( Table 2). The BET surface areas (SBET) for MC/AC and PMC/AC catalysts were 830 and 662 m2·g−1, respectively, and their corresponding total pore volume (Vtotal) were 0.39 and 0.34 cm3·g−1, indicating that PbCl2 poisoning could obviously damage the structure of these pores for fresh MC/AC catalysts. Besides, the SBET for CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC catalysts were 772, 741 and 723 m2·g−1, respectively, and their corresponding Vtotal were 0.37, 0.36 and 0.36 cm3·g−1, meaning that the pore structure for PMC/AC catalyst was partially restored after doping with the three transition metal oxides. It might be the reason of their good dispersion properties which inhibited the crystallization for the substance on catalyst surface [40]. This was consistent with XRD analysis. Besides, SBET and Vtotal value sequence was similar to the order of variation in catalytic activity of the catalysts. In general, a larger SBET of catalyst would provide more active sites for the reactants participating in the catalytic reactions. The average pore diameter was essentially the same for all poisoned catalysts, suggesting that the transition metals (Cu, Co and Zr) modifications had little effect on them. 3.4 SEM results The microscopic morphology and surface element distribution of the fresh MC/AC and poisoned catalysts were shown in Fig. 4. From Fig. 4(a), the surface for MC/AC catalyst was rough and had numerous micro pores, allowing for good contact between active components and reaction gas. Corresponding EDS characterization images for MC/AC catalyst showed that the MnO x and CeO x on the fresh catalyst surface were highly dispersed. For PMC/AC catalyst (Fig. 4(g)), the surface was almost completely covered with Pb elements, causing the catalyst surface to become rough and the pores to become clogged, reducing the catalyst’s ability to adsorb reaction gases. As shown in Fig. 4(c)–(e), CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC, and ZrPMC/AC catalysts, on the other hand, had much lower surface Pb coverage than that of PMC/AC catalyst. This suggested that Cu, Co, and Zr could promote the uniform dispersion of Pb species over catalyst surface, which was in line with EDS analysis. 3.5 H2-TPR results Redox performance for MC/AC and PbCl2-poisoned samples was characterized using H2-TPR test, and the corresponding results were shown in Fig. 5 and Table 3. Fig. 5 showed that the H2-TPR profiles for these catalysts had a broader peak at 100–850 °C, which could be deconvoluted to three peaks and labeled as I, II and III, respectively. As for MC/AC or PMC/AC catalyst, the peak I was corresponded to the reduction of MnO2 to Mn2O3 for chemisorbed oxygen; Peak II was attributed to Mn2O3 to Mn3O4 and surface CeO2 to Ce2O3; The peak III was ascribed to Mn3O4 to MnO and the bulk CeO2 reduction [40–43]. Additionally, for CuPMC/AC catalyst, the peak I also included the reduction process of Cu2+→Cu+→Cu0 [44]. For CoPMC/AC catalyst, the reduction process of Co3+→Co2+→Co0 at 380–470 °C was attributed to peaks I and II [45]. The redox properties of catalysts were reported to depend on reduction temperature and peak area [46]. As seen from Table 3, the initial reduction temperature and peak area for MC/AC catalyst was 330 °C and 3049 a.u., respectively. However, after lead poisoning, the reduction temperature of PMC/AC catalyst increased to 350 °C and the peak area decreased to 1789 a.u. It indicated that the addition of PbCl2 species severely disrupted redox ability of MC/AC catalyst. Compared with PMC/AC catalyst, the initial reduction temperature of CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC samples was shifted to the lower temperature and peak area increasing. For all poisoned catalysts, both the reduction temperature and peak area followed the priority of CuPMC/AC > CoPMC/AC > ZrPMC/AC catalyst, which coincided with the catalytic activity result. It implied that the breaking level of redox properties caused by PbCl2 over transition metal M (Cu, Co, Zr) oxides modified catalyst was much lower than that of the fresh MC/AC catalyst. Surprisingly, CuO x had the best redox characteristics of the three transition metals modified PMC/AC catalysts, which was one of the important reasons for its superior lead resistance. 3.6 NH3-TPD results Surface acidity was an important physical parameter that determined NO reduction degree with NH3 in NH3-SCR reaction of Mn-based catalysts [47]. The NH3-TPD test was used for quantitative and qualitative analysis of the surface acidity of MC/AC and PbCl2 poisoned catalysts. Fig. 6 showed the NH3-TPD curves for all catalysts and they could be divided into three parts for desorption peaks (labeled as α, β and γ) in the measured temperature range. According to previous literatures [29,48,49], α peak (<150 °C) was corresponding to NH3 species adsorbed on weak acid sites; β peak (150–300 °C) represented the NH3 species on medium-strong acid sites and γ peak (300–500 °C) stood for NH3 species adsorbed on strong acid sites. NH3 adsorption amount for each catalyst was obtained by area integration of the corresponding NH3-TPD curve, and the results were listed in Table 4. The sequence of the total acid amount (i.e., ST) for all samples was as follows: MC/AC > CuPMC/AC > CoPMC/AC > ZrPMC/AC > PMC/AC catalyst, which was also in line with NO conversion result. From the table, the ST for MC/AC catalyst was 7475 a.u. while PMC/AC catalyst was 3829 a.u., a decrease of ca. 48.7%, indicating that PbCl2 loading destructed the total acid sites greatly. The ST for CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC catalysts was 7010 a.u., 5516 a.u. and 4748 a.u., respectively, which were all higher than that of PMC/AC catalyst. The surface acidity determined NH3 adsorption, which was an important step for NH3-SCR reaction, and it might be another important reason for good lead resistance of the transition metal (Cu, Co and Zr) oxides modified PMC/AC catalysts [8]. 3.7 XPS results XPS test was conducted to further investigate the concentration and valence states of active components of MC/AC and PbCl2-poisoned catalysts. The XPS spectra and peak fitting results of Mn 2p, Ce 3d and O 1 s were given in Fig. 7. And the relevant element concentration ratios were summarized and shown in Table 5. Fig. 7(a) showed O 1 s XPS profiles of all samples, with the O 1 s peaks split into two peaks located at 529.3–530.6 eV and 531.2–533.6 eV, which were corresponding to lattice oxygen (marked as Olatt) and surface adsorbed oxygen species (marked as Oads) [50]. It was discovered that the higher Oads/(Olatt+Oads) ratio, the better NH3-SCR reaction ability [51]. It was due to the fact that Oads could enhance the oxidation of NO to NO2, resulting in the “fast SCR” reactions [52]. As shown in Table 5, the Oads percentage for MC/AC catalyst was 97%, which was significantly higher than that of PMC/AC catalyst (78%). It was suggested that the PbCl2 loading inhibited the enrichment of Oads on MC/AC catalyst surface. With the doping of Cu, Co and Zr oxides, the Oads atoms concentration on PMC/AC catalyst surface increased to 93%, 86% and 82%, respectively. It was also found that the percentage of Oads on CuPMC/AC catalyst surface was relatively high, which might be an important contribution for the best Pb resistance of Cu-modified MC/AC catalyst. The XPS patterns of Mn 2p for all samples were presented in Fig. 7(b), which consisted of two peaks of Mn 2p3/2 (~641.2 eV) and Mn 2p1/2 (~653.1 eV). Among them, Mn 2p3/2 could be fitted into the peaks Mn4+ (644.4–644.9 eV), Mn3+ (642.5–643.2 eV) and Mn2+ (639.5–641.3 eV), respectively[11,15]. As listed in Table 5, the Mn4+/(Mn4++Mn3++Mn2+) ratios for MC/AC and PMC/AC were 27% and 17%, which implied that the PbCl2 loading prevented the right shift of redox reaction (4). (4) M n 3 + + C e 4 + ↔ M n 4 + + C e 3 + Besides, the Mn4+ ratios of CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC catalysts were 27%, 25% and 22%, respectively. This further proved the electron transfer between transition metal Mn+ (M=Cu, Co and Zr) and Mnn+ or/and Cen+. Studies had shown that high ratio of Mn4+ for Mn-based low-temperature catalysts was conducive to promoting SCR activity, because Mn4+ helped NO oxidizing to NO2 and improved catalytic activity via the “fast SCR” reaction process [12,16]. It was also one of the reasons why the NO conversion of CuPMC/AC catalyst was higher than that of CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC samples. Fig. 7(c) was the XPS pattern of Ce 3d for all samples. As shown in the figure, eight peaks could be observed at 915.7, 907.3, 903.6, 900.4, 897.4, 889.3, 885.1 and 881.3 eV, respectively. Among them, the peaks at 903.6 and 885.1 eV were attributed to Ce3+, while the peaks at 915.7, 907.3, 900.4, 897.4, 889.3 and 881.3 eV were ascribed to Ce4+ [53,54]. The results illustrated that coexistence of Ce element on all catalyst surfaces was mainly in the form of Ce3+ and Ce4+. It was demonstrated that the more Ce3+ species could result in redox electron transfer and the formation of oxygen vacancies, facilitating the NH3-SCR reaction [6,55–57]. The Ce3+ ratios on MC/AC and PMC/AC catalyst surface were 39% and 35%, respectively, as shown in Table 5, suggesting that PbCl2 hindered the formation of Ce3+ on MC/AC sample. The surface Ce3+ content of CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC, and ZrPMC/AC catalysts was close, implying that the transition metal oxides had little influence on Ce3+ formation over PMC/AC catalyst. 3.8 H2O and SO2 resistance test results In the actual application, SO2 and H2O in the reaction environment could easily result in catalyst deactivation in NH3-SCR process. So, the NO conversion for all fresh and PbCl2-poisoned catalysts was tested with the presence of H2O or SO2 + H2O at 200 °C, and the results were given in Fig. 8. As seen, without the presence of H2O or SO2 + H2O, the catalytic activity for all samples remained constant within 2 h, then the NO conversion for all catalysts reduced by ca. 10% when only 5% H2O was added to the reactor and stayed steady for another 2 h. The decrease of NO conversion was primarily due to the fact that H2O inhibited NH3 adsorption on the active sites and increased ammonium sulfate formation on the catalyst [58]. After adding 100 ppm SO2, the NO conversion for all catalysts presented a continuous downward trend within 8 h. As seen in Fig. 8(a), the catalytic activity of ZrMC/AC was better than that of CoMC/AC, CuMC/AC and MC/AC catalysts with the coexistence of H2O and SO2. However, for PbCl2-poisoned catalysts from Fig. 8(b), the catalytic activity was in the order of CuPMC/AC > CoPMC/AC > ZrPMC/AC > MC/AC catalyst. After shutting down SO2 +H2O, NO conversion of all catalysts increased but did not return to original level. This implied that the deactivation of all catalysts was a combination of reversible and irreversible deactivation processes [19]. On the one hand, competitive adsorption between H2O and reaction gas resulted in reversible deactivation. On the other hand, the deactivation of the catalyst by metal sulphates and (NH4)2SO4 (or NH4HSO4) was irreversible [58]. 3.9 In situ DRIFTS analysis In situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out to investigate the adsorption and reaction behavior for NH3 and NO on the surface of poisoned or anti-poisoning catalysts, and the SCR reaction path over the catalysts surface was analyzed according to the transient reaction results. 3.9.1 NH3 adsorption In situ DRIFTS firstly was used to research the effect of transition metal oxides modification on the NH3 adsorption for PMC/AC catalyst and the results were shown in Fig. 9. The catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C for 60 min with the N2 protective atmosphere before cooling to 200 °C. After 30 min of continuous N2 exposure, the background spectrum was collected. 60 min later, the gas was changed to 500 ppm NH3/N2, and the infrared spectrum was continually collected. The infrared spectra for NH3 adsorbed on all catalyst surfaces were shown in Fig. 9. After NH3 pretreatment, the peaks at 3400–3000 cm−1 of all samples were assigned to the N-H stretching vibration for coordinated NH3 [53,59]. The peaks (1627, 1619, 1249 and 1103 cm−1) were described to coordinated NH3 absorbed on L acid sites, ionic NH4 + absorbed on B acid sites was attributed to the peaks at 1747, 1689, 1685, 1411, and 1365 cm−1 [7,19,59,60]. The peaks at 1527 and 1068 cm−1 corresponded to -NH2, which was the reason of dehydrogenation for NH3 adsorbed on active sites [34]. It was found that -NH2 was a vital intermediate for NH3-SCR process and could react directly with NO [61]. Furthermore, for CuPMC/AC catalyst, a negative peak was seen at ca. 1388 cm−1, which was mostly attributed to the generation of NH4 + by interaction of NH3 adsorbed on the surface of catalyst and hydroxyl groups on the surface of AC carrier [62]. PMC/AC, CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC catalysts had similar DRIFTS curves (Fig. 9). It was also discovered that L and B acid sites coexisted on all catalysts, which was in line with the results of NH3-TPD. Besides, the addition of transition metal (Cu, Co and Zr) oxides aided the adsorption of NH3. It was well understood that ionic NH4 + and coordination NH3 both played key roles in the NH3-SCR reaction [45]. The higher concentration of L acid sites and B acid sites over the transition metal oxides modified PMC/AC catalysts could explain their good low-temperature SCR performance after lead poisoning. 3.9.2 NO+O2 adsorption The in situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out on all catalysts to explore the adsorption behavior of NO+O2 on catalyst surfaces. The experimental conditions were the same as NH3 adsorption experiment and the spectra were shown in Fig. 10. When NO+O2 was introduced, the peak at 1846 cm−1 was assigned to the adsorbed NO; the peak at 1619 cm−1 associated with gaseous NO2 molecules on catalyst surface and adsorbed NO2; and the peak (1527 cm−1) was related to bidentate nitrate; the peak at 1380 cm−1 corresponded to monodentate nitrate and the peak (1303 cm−1) was ascribed to monodentate nitrite [34,63]. In general, PMC/AC catalyst had more nitrogen oxide species adsorbing on its surface, while the total number of nitrate species on the transition metal oxides modified PMC/AC catalysts surface was greater. 3.9.3 Transient experiment for pre-adsorption NH3 and NO+O2 To explore which form of NH3 participating in SCR reaction, in situ DRIFTS experiment between pre-adsorbed NH3 and NO+O2 was performed at 200 °C. Firstly, the catalysts were pretreated at 300 °C for 60 min under N2 protective atmosphere and then cooling to 200 °C. After 30 min of continuous N2 purge, the sample background was collected.Then 500 ppm NH3/N2 was injected into the infrared reaction tank for 60 min, followed by N2 purging 30 min, and then switching to 7 vol% O2 + 500 ppm NO/N2 for 60 min. The spectra of poisoned catalysts were given in Fig. 11. Fig. 11(a) was the infrared spectrum for PMC/AC catalyst. It was discovered that after NH3 adsorbing on PMC/AC catalyst for 60 min and then purged with N2 for 30 min, the peak position nearly had no change, but its intensity corresponding to the coordinated NH3 became weaker, implying that the adsorption capacity for NH3 of PMC/AC surface was weaker. For pre-adsorbed NH3 species, coordination NH3 locating 1619 cm−1 and -NH2 locating 1076 cm−1 vanished within 1 min while the peaks of coordinated NH3 at 3400–3000 and 1253 cm−1 could be detected after 40 min. This indicated that not all NH3 species adsorbing on acid sites had high reactivity. When NO+O2 passed through for 5 min, the peak locating 1897 cm−1 was attributed to adsorbed NO, the peak at 1600 cm−1 was associated with gaseous NO2 molecules, and the peaks (1137 and 1064 cm−1) ascribed to cis-N2O2 2- and NO- all appeared. Fig. 11(b–d) showed the spectra of CuPMC/AC, CoPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC catalysts for NO+O2 adsorption after pre-adsorption of NH3. The NH3 adsorption behavior on the transition metal oxides modified PMC/AC catalysts was similar and the coordinated NH3 (locating 3400–3000 cm−1) or -NH2 (ca. 1527 cm−1) could also be found. For CuPMC/AC catalyst, the peak of coordinated NH3 at 1253 cm−1 still existed after NO+O2 treatment for 40 min. Such phenomena were also observed for NH4 + at 1527 cm−1 for ZrPMC/AC catalyst. It suggested that the reactivity for NH3 species adsorbing on the L and B acid sites of CuPMC/AC and ZrPMC/AC catalysts was not high. However, for CoPMC/AC catalyst, the peaks located at 1527 and 1253 cm−1 for the adsorbed NH3 species disappeared completely at 5 min after the introduction of NO+O2. In addition, the above results showed that the SCR reactions of PbCl2-poisoned samples followed E-R mechanism. 3.9.4 Transient experiment for pre-adsorption NO+O2 and NH3 In situ DRIFTS experiment was performed between pre-adsorbed NO+O2 and NH3 at ca. 200 °C to investigate which form of NO x species participating in NH3-SCR reactions. The experiment procedure was similar with the describing in Section 3.9.3, and the DRIFTS spectra were displayed in Fig. 12. In all samples, main NO x species on the surface of catalyst after adsorbed NO+O2 for 60 min were mostly gaseous NO2 molecules (locating 1619 cm−1) and monodentate nitrate (locating 1376 cm−1). From Fig. 12, the peak of gaseous NO2 (1619 cm−1) vanished quickly after NH3 passed through all of the pre-adsorbed NO+O2 samples, whereas the peak for monodentate nitrate (1376 cm−1) only changed slightly. This indicated that gaseous NO2 was the primary active substance in SCR reactions on the PbCl2-poisoned catalysts, while the monodentate nitrate was less reactive. After the nitrate was consumed, the DRIFTS peaks (locating 3400–3000, 1616, 1253 and 1122 cm−1) belonged to coordinated NH3; the peaks (locating 1751 and 1600 cm−1) were related to ionic NH4 + adsorbing on B acid sites and the peak (1519 cm−1) was ascribed to -NH2 species. Furthermore, transient in situ DRIFTS experiments for pre-adsorbed NO+O2 and NH3 had shown that all NH3-SCR reactions with PbCl2-poisoned catalysts followed L-H mechanism. 3.10 Possible anti-PbCl2 poisoning mechanism of M (M = Cu, Co and Zr)-doped Mn-Ce/AC catalysts In situ DRIFTS NH3 adsorption results implied that gaseous NH3 molecules were present on the surface of the poisoned catalysts primarily with the form of adsorbed coordinated NH3, ionic NH4 + and -NH2. The in situ DRIFTS analysis of NO+O2 adsorption revealed that NO molecules were mostly present on the poisoned catalyst surface in the form of NO2 molecules and monodentate nitrates. E-R and L-H mechanisms (Eqs. (5–14)) accounted for the low-temperature SCR reaction pathways for PbCl2-poisoned catalysts when combined with transient in situ DRIFTS studies for NH3 and NO+O2 on all poisoned catalysts. (5) O 2 ( g ) → 2 O ( a d s ) (6) N O ( g ) + O ( a d s ) → N O 2 ( a d s ) (7) N H 3 ( g ) → N H 3 ( a d s ) (8) N H 3 ( g ) + H + → N H 4 + ( ads ) (9) M n + + N H 3 ( a d s ) → M ( n − 1 ) + + − N H 2 ( a d s ) + H + (10) ( M n + = M n 4 + , C e 4 + , C u 2 + a n d C o 2 + ) M n + + N O 2 ( a d s ) → M n + + N O 3 − ( monodentate nitrate ) (11) − N H 2 ( ads ) + NO ( g ) → NH 2 NO → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( E − R mechanism ) (12) N H 4 + ( a d s ) + N O 2 ( a d s ) + e − → N H 4 N O 2 → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O ( L − H mechanism ) (13) N O 3 − ( a d s ) + N H 4 + ( ads ) → NH 4 NO 3 → N 2 ( g ) + H 2 O + N O 2 ( g ) ( L − H mechanism ) (14) N O 3 − ( a d s ) + N H 4 + ( a d s ) → N H 4 N O 3 → N 2 O ( g ) + H 2 O ( L − H mechanism ) Above all, three transition metal (Cu, Co, and Zr) oxides improved the resistance of MC/AC catalysts to PbCl2, with Cu oxide being the most effective modifier. As we explored the physicochemical properties of the poisoned samples, the possible lead resistance mechanisms of the three transition metal oxides modified catalysts were as follows. According to the XRD results, the doping of Cu, Co and Zr oxides effectively weakened the crystallinity of the active substances Ce and Mn on the surface of MC/AC catalyst after poisoning. NH3 adsorption and activation on the surface of catalyst was a vital process in the SCR reactions, which was mainly determined by the surface acidity and redox properties of active sites. H2-TPR analysis showed that the redox performance of Cu, Co and Zr oxides modified PMC/AC catalyst was higher than PMC/AC itself, which favored the SCR reactions. The NH3-TPD experiment revealed that Cu, Co and Zr oxides modification greatly increased the surface acidity of PMC/AC catalyst, which was contributed to adsorption and activation for NH3 species. Furthermore, the redox properties and surface acidity of the poisoned samples were as follows: CuPMC/AC > CoPMC/AC > ZrPMC/AC > PMC/AC catalysts. In addition, XPS results revealed that the content of chemisorbed oxygen and Mn4+ on transition metal oxides modified PMC/AC catalyst was higher than that on PMC/AC itself, which was advantageous to the “fast SCR” reaction process. All of these factors were favorable for increasing the Pb resistance of MC/AC catalyst and the above analysis was summarized and shown in Fig. 13. 4 Conclusions The effects of Cu, Co and Zr oxides doped MC/AC catalyst on anti-PbCl2 poisoning performance were investigated for the current work. The results showed that three transition metal oxides modified MC/AC catalysts were effective in improving their resistance to PbCl2 poisoning and retaining the excellent low temperature catalytic activity of MC/AC catalyst. Among them, the Cu-modified MC/AC sample showed the best PbCl2 resistance, with the NO conversion of ca. 81% at 225 °C after poisoning. Furthermore, CuPMC/AC catalyst maintained more than 90% N2 selectivity during 75–250 °C, and H2O or SO2 + H2O resistance performance for CuPMC/AC sample was also better than other poisoned catalysts obviously. XRD and BET results showed that three transition metal oxides modification could effectively counteract the decrease in the specific surface area and increase in surface crystallinity of catalyst after lead poisoning. According to the XPS results, the addition of Cu, Co and Zr oxides minimized the downward trend of surface adsorbed oxygen (Oads) and Mn4+ content. Furthermore, the transition metal oxides modifications improved the redox properties and surface acidity of the poisoned samples and were in the order of CuPMC/AC > CoPMC/AC > ZrPMC/AC > PMC/AC catalysts, according to the analysis of H2-TPR and NH3-TPD. The in situ DRIFTS analysis revealed that all poisoned catalysts SCR reaction pathways were controlled by a combination of E-R and L-H mechanisms. Finally, a possible anti-PbCl2 poisoning mechanistic model for transition metal oxides modification on MC/AC catalyst was proposed. coredata.dc:description: Lead salts poisoning was a great challenge for the catalysts application in selective catalytic reduction (SCR) reaction of NO x with NH3 in stationary sources. Herein, several typical transition metal (Cu, Co and Zr) oxides modified Mn-Ce/AC catalysts were prepared by impregnation method, and the effects of Cu, Co and Zr doping on resistance PbCl2 poisoning for the catalyst were investigated. The addition of three transition metal oxides improved the PbCl2 resistance of Mn-Ce/AC catalyst and maintained excellent low-temperature denitrification activity of the catalyst. The lead resistance performance of the three metal oxides followed: Cu > Co > Zr oxides. The NO conversion of Cu-doping catalyst after PbCl2 poisoning was only ca. 10% lower than that of fresh Mn-Ce/AC catalyst at 225 °C. Cu, Co and Zr doping could decrease the loss of specific surface area caused by poisoning, while Cu-doped catalyst showed lowest crystallinity of active components. Meanwhile, the contents of Mn4+ and chemisorbed oxygen in Cu-doped catalyst were higher than those in Co- or Zr-doped catalysts. Cu, Co and Zr doping improved the surface acidity and redox performance of the poisoned catalysts, with Cu-doped poisoned catalyst exhibiting nearly the same surface acidity and redox performance as the fresh Mn-Ce/AC catalyst. Furthermore, Cu doping could also improve NO adsorption and was in favor to the SCR process. Besides, in situ DRIFTS results showed that the catalytic reaction pathways of all the poisoned or modified catalysts were in accordance with both Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) and Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanisms. Finally, a possible anti-PbCl2 poisoning mechanistic model of (Cu, Co and Zr) oxides modified on Mn-Ce/AC catalyst was proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Revealing M (M = Cu, Co and Zr) oxides doping effects on anti-PbCl2 poisoning over Mn-Ce/AC catalysts in low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction
